@Cristian_BNB @ProfRachelGaN @royalsociety The @royalsociety recognise that diversity is the key to successful and excellent science and therefore do what they can to support and encourage this.

@Cristian_BNB @ProfRachelGaN @royalsociety Think about how many discoveries have not yet been made-or were heavily delayed-because of the diversity that has been actively excluded in the past. The status quo only works for those who have always benefited from it. Making science accessible to all is definitely THE KEY.

@royalsociety @Cristian_BNB @GilesPalaeoLab Superb. EXACTLY the kind of response our professional and learned societies should be making to this kind of outdated view of science as a rarefied pursuit isolated from wider society.

It was certainly an exciting four days for @BasketballNB & @FHS_VGBB player @allie7mccarthy & BNB U17 girls' coach @P_Kelly17 attending @CanBball age class U16 assessment camp in Edmonton. Always proud to wear a maple leaf!  https://t.co/NtUdoyPhUe

@Cristian_BNB @royalsociety @GilesPalaeoLab Or, it could be that science doesn't happen in a vacuum, scientists and access to science is influenced by wider society? Anyway, I'm blocking you now, because I'm too busy doing science to argue with people on Twitter who think I can't "because feminism".

@Cristian_BNB @ProfRachelGaN @royalsociety Yes, I’m 100% saying that women (and other underrepresented groups) are still excluded from science. That’s why they’re underrepresented. Some progress had been made, but there’s by no means equal opportunity. There’s a whole host of literature that you’ve refused to engage with.

@Cristian_BNB @ProfRachelGaN @royalsociety 🤔 A tiny, tiny proportion of the women and minority scientists who had the potential to do great science managed to make it (often at great cost). They are historically, and currently, underrepresented. I (and @royalsociety) et al want to tackle the barriers that led to that.

@Cristian_BNB @ProfRachelGaN @royalsociety Y’know, I do. And in particular with people who were historically (and more recently) told by others that they couldn’t do science! Strangely enough the people who were told this tended to be women and minorities. That’s why they tend to be underrepresented in science today.

@Cristian_BNB @ProfRachelGaN @royalsociety Yes, the men who pioneered science had to fight and work hard. But they did it in the context that they were male and (mostly) white and therefore weren't excluded from doing their science by the law or culture or other people's unscientific and unsubstantiated opinions.

@Cristian_BNB @ProfRachelGaN @royalsociety You are talking to one (1) woman (and a gay one at that) who has made a career in science. The fact that I have in no way contradicts the mountain of barriers to other women and other minorities in science. I again refer you to the literature that you haven't engaged with.

@Cristian_BNB @ProfRachelGaN @royalsociety I can see where this is going, but I don’t believe there are any fundamental biological or psychological reasons why a male or a female or anyone else should be better at being a sewage worker or nursery nurse or scientist. Did you read any relevant lierature yet?

@Cristian_BNB @royalsociety I don’t see anything in there at odds with what @royalsociety said. Many people have tried to engage you in sensible debate and you continue to display your bias and prejudices, without attempting to listen or learn. PS you have no idea the gender or qualifications of their team.
